date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024

top_reviews.title: Comfortable!
top_reviews.body: I had been using the default controller my ps4 came with way back in March 2015 until it really became worn down. I’m talking rubber worn off the joysticks and stick shift. And the joystick felt too loose. (Doesn’t feel firm anymore)  Brought this as a replacement and it really felt like an upgrade. The color is fresh and the grips feel more comfortable than the PS4 model. Playing games with it for the first time, it was great! Definitely would recommend this controller to anyone looking for an upgrade. (Forgot to mention, it even comes with modded buttons underneath next to the trigger buttons)Read more
top_reviews.body_html:

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023

top_reviews.title: Average 3rd party controller
top_reviews.body: I wasn't very impressed with the look and feel of this controller. It honestly does not have the premium feel I thought it would and the lack of weight makes it feel somewhat cheap in my hands.  It is definitely an all plastic build but what worries me is that it seems to be a one piece shell controller. In other words, I don't see any screws holding the controller together. So if something does break or you have to change out the built-in rechargeable battery, you won't be able to.  The handles of the controller do have a textured pattern to prevent the controller from slipping out of your hands. One of the major pros is the fact that the joysticks are actual rubber making it comfortable for your thumbs.  I've only tried the controller on my PlayStation 4 but the instructions state that it can be connected to the PS5 as well? I'll try and use the controller on my PlayStation 5 and make any needed edits or updates to my review afterwards.Read more
top_reviews.body_html:
I wasn't very impressed with the look and feel of this controller. It honestly does not have the premium feel I thought it would and the lack of weight makes it feel somewhat cheap in my hands.

It is definitely an all plastic build but what worries me is that it seems to be a one piece shell controller. In other words, I don't see any screws holding the controller together. So if something does break or you have to change out the built-in rechargeable battery, you won't be able to.

The handles of the controller do have a textured pattern to prevent the controller from slipping out of your hands. One of the major pros is the fact that the joysticks are actual rubber making it comfortable for your thumbs.

I've only tried the controller on my PlayStation 4 but the instructions state that it can be connected to the PS5 as well? I'll try and use the controller on my PlayStation 5 and make any needed edits or updates to my review afterwards.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2023

top_reviews.title: Compatible with PS4, with Turbo function and 2 additional programmable buttons on the back
top_reviews.body: I used this product with my PlayStation4 only, so cannot attest to its compatibility with the additonal devices listed in the description.  This controller is designed in a similar shape as the PS5 DualSense controllers from Sony, rather than the typical PS4 DualShock controller design, but IS compatible with PS4 consoles. Feels comfortable in the hands, though slightly odd at first due to its design difference from other PS4 controllers. The buttons and triggers feel very responsive and smooth-moving, more so than any other generic controller I have used.  Included in the packaging is instructions for how to program the 2 additional buttons on the underside of the controller. These buttons can each be used for copying the function of one of the other buttons/triggers on the controller, not for additional commands (as far as I have been able to tell).  A "Turbo" button is also built in to the controller, with instructions for how to use it. I have not attempted use of the Turbo function at the time of this review.  This controller charges via the included USB --> USB-c cable, rather than micro-USB. Also included in the packaging is 2 multi-colored joystick covers/grips for use if so desired.Read more
top_reviews.body_html:
I used this product with my PlayStation4 only, so cannot attest to its compatibility with the additonal devices listed in the description.

This controller is designed in a similar shape as the PS5 DualSense controllers from Sony, rather than the typical PS4 DualShock controller design, but IS compatible with PS4 consoles. Feels comfortable in the hands, though slightly odd at first due to its design difference from other PS4 controllers. The buttons and triggers feel very responsive and smooth-moving, more so than any other generic controller I have used.

Included in the packaging is instructions for how to program the 2 additional buttons on the underside of the controller. These buttons can each be used for copying the function of one of the other buttons/triggers on the controller, not for additional commands (as far as I have been able to tell).

A "Turbo" button is also built in to the controller, with instructions for how to use it. I have not attempted use of the Turbo function at the time of this review.

This controller charges via the included USB --> USB-c cable, rather than micro-USB. Also included in the packaging is 2 multi-colored joystick covers/grips for use if so desired.

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2023

top_reviews.title: Great Controller
top_reviews.body: This controller is fantastic! We use it in our house with the PS4 and while it is a slightly different style and hold than the traditional PS4 controller it is really great. The design fits in your hands well the extra buttons you can program make some games easier with the location. It has a good weight to it and it holds a good charge. It's become a favorite controller in my house.Read more

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023

top_reviews.title: Great PS4 controller
top_reviews.body: Wasn’t 100% sure how this one would perform but it does great. Able to play many games with great performance. Playing MLB 23 and have to put a pitch in a tight spot? It’s sensitive enough to do that. Solid response with shooting and driving games as well. Cool little grips for the joysticks as well and holds a charge just as well as Sony controllers. Solid buy for much less. Has handled some drops, including one down the stairs and keeps working. Definitely 5 stars here after a couple tough weeks of use.Read more
top_reviews.body_html:

date.raw: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2023

top_reviews.title: Decent controller for a great price
top_reviews.body: First of all, I think that it's important to preface that I'm mainly a PC gamer. I don't use a controller very often unless it's for something like Dark Souls or Elden Ring, and when I do, I'll usually just use whatever I have laying around. In the past, that's been an old wired Xbox 360 controller- unfortunately, the cable finally frayed and it wouldn't work anymore without some serious finagling, so I figured it was time to upgrade to something more recent.  That's where this controller comes into the picture! It's got a nice hand feel, and I like all of it's features. It comes with two joystick covers included, which is nice because they provide some extra traction. Unfortunately, I also think that they could have put a little bit more attention into the joysticks themselves, as I find them a little "light". I would prefer for them to have some more resistance to them, as sometimes it can feel like I'm not even pushing them, but that might just be a personal preference. The buttons come with icons printed on top, but the designs are a little strange. I guess they have to have them like that for copyright reasons. I also like the addition of a Turbo button, which allows you to quickly map inputs to the paddles on the back of the controller. This is especially useful when you need to hit the same button repeatedly, such as during quick time button mashing events, or if you need to spam jumping in something like Mario Maker. I haven't used the gyro / motion controls or the touch pad much yet, but they also seem to be very accurate. I definitely plan on using them in the future for stuff like CEMU or YUZU, where a lack of motion controls can be a severe disadvantage (I'm looking at you, BOTW puzzle shrines).  Like I said before, I normally use wired controllers, but the latency with this one doesn't seem too bad. I use a Bluetooth 5.3 adapter with my PC, and according to DS4Windows, the latency hovers around 12-13ms. I hardly notice any type of delay, but if it's absolutely necessary to have the lowest latency possible, you can also use it as a wired controller by plugging the USB-C charging cable into your PC. In this setup, the latency drops down to about 4.5ms, which is much better. Overall, I would definitely recommend this controller, and the $25-$26 price point appears to be pretty much in-line with its competitors.Read more
top_reviews.body_html:
First of all, I think that it's important to preface that I'm mainly a PC gamer. I don't use a controller very often unless it's for something like Dark Souls or Elden Ring, and when I do, I'll usually just use whatever I have laying around. In the past, that's been an old wired Xbox 360 controller- unfortunately, the cable finally frayed and it wouldn't work anymore without some serious finagling, so I figured it was time to upgrade to something more recent.

That's where this controller comes into the picture! It's got a nice hand feel, and I like all of it's features. It comes with two joystick covers included, which is nice because they provide some extra traction. Unfortunately, I also think that they could have put a little bit more attention into the joysticks themselves, as I find them a little "light". I would prefer for them to have some more resistance to them, as sometimes it can feel like I'm not even pushing them, but that might just be a personal preference. The buttons come with icons printed on top, but the designs are a little strange. I guess they have to have them like that for copyright reasons. I also like the addition of a Turbo button, which allows you to quickly map inputs to the paddles on the back of the controller. This is especially useful when you need to hit the same button repeatedly, such as during quick time button mashing events, or if you need to spam jumping in something like Mario Maker. I haven't used the gyro / motion controls or the touch pad much yet, but they also seem to be very accurate. I definitely plan on using them in the future for stuff like CEMU or YUZU, where a lack of motion controls can be a severe disadvantage (I'm looking at you, BOTW puzzle shrines).

Like I said before, I normally use wired controllers, but the latency with this one doesn't seem too bad. I use a Bluetooth 5.3 adapter with my PC, and according to DS4Windows, the latency hovers around 12-13ms. I hardly notice any type of delay, but if it's absolutely necessary to have the lowest latency possible, you can also use it as a wired controller by plugging the USB-C charging cable into your PC. In this setup, the latency drops down to about 4.5ms, which is much better. Overall, I would definitely recommend this controller, and the $25-$26 price point appears to be pretty much in-line with its competitors.
